Award.AwardTitle: Determining Structural Ensembles for Intrinsically Unstructured Proteins

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project to is study structural variations in a family of intrinsically unstructured proteins (IUP). Based on the PI's previous work, and the work of others, it is now clear that IUPs form a diverse set of protein families that can elicit biological function using a variety of mechanisms. This project has two aims: (I) Determine structural ensembles for a set of homologous proteins that are intrinsically unstructured. In this specific aim, paramagnetic relaxation enhancement will be used to estimate long-range interatomic distances that can be used to restrain structure calculations. The structural ensembles will then be validated using residual dipolar couplings and small angle x-ray scattering. (II) Determine the relationship between sequence identity and structural similarity for a set of homologous proteins that are intrinsically unstructured. In this specific aim, eigenvector decomposition of protein contact maps will be used to identify similarities between the structural ensembles. This data will then be correlated with genetic distance matrices to determine the percent sequence identity necessary for structural similarity. Experiments in this specific aim will also test the importance of amino acid composition for specifying the structural ensemble. Successful completion of both specific aims will facilitate the development of models of protein evolution for intrinsically unstructured proteins that can be used to estimate their dynamic structures based on sequence identity.

The PI has a strong record of advancing discovery and understanding while promoting teaching, training, and learning. This is evidenced by the three peer reviewed publications that have undergraduate students as authors and five peer reviewed publications that have authors from underrepresented groups. The PI is also very committed in disseminating scientific information to general public. In the summer of 2004, the PI participated in a state funded workshop for secondary education to science teachers. The PI gave lectures on the general principles of protein structure and function as well as a tutorial for using molecular graphics programs in the classroom. This project will involve two undergraduate students and a female research technician and the PI will continue his efforts to involve science teachers in basic scientific research by holding an annual workshop whose purpose would be to introduce science teachers to the latest breakthroughs and make them aware of new web-based tools for scientific discovery.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research objectives for award MCB-0939014 are to determine structural ensembles for a set of orthologous proteins that are intrinsically unstructured and use these ensembles to identify relationships between sequence identity and structural similarity. Major accomplishments during the funding period include the development of a new method for analyzing the structural ensembles of intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPDs). This method bypasses traditional structure based approaches by performing principle component analysis directly on atomic contact maps. We also made a comprehensive comparison of evolutionary models for ordered and disordered proteins and showed that infrequent residues found in the protein binding sites of IDPDs are highly conserved. More recently, in collaboration with Dr. Ytreberg, a new method was developed that combines experiment and computer simulations to generate all atom structural ensembles of IDPDs. One published book chapter and two published manuscript demonstrates that it performs well with both small angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) data and NMR chemical shifts and for the first time demonstrates that common structural features can be detected in multiple independently generated ensembles. We also recently demonstrated that disorder predictors could reliably predict the backbone dynamics of a family of IDPDs and for this same family we showed that structural divergence is more extensive than sequence divergence. In collaboration with Dr. Phil Selenko and Dr. Alexander Loewer we demonstrated that the levels of disorder and residual helicity in an IDP controlled its ability to function properly in the test tube and inside living cells. 

Broader impacts of the current NSF support include training postdoctoral scientists, undergraduate students and graduate students. Two postdoctoral scientists, Hongwei Wu and Stepan Kashtanov, have worked on the project. Dr. Wu is a co-author on one book chapter and five published manuscript. He recently accepted a Research Faculty position at the University of Indiana Chemistry Department. Dr. Kashtanov is a co-author on one book chapter and two published manuscripts. Two undergraduate students have worked on the project. One of these students, A. Stancik, is a co-author on a published manuscript and is currently a research technician in a former colleagues laboratory at the University of Idaho. The other student, K. Mishal, received an REU supplement to work on the project in Summer 2010 and is a co-author on the Nature Chemical Biology pubication from 2014. She recently accepted an appointment to the Cancer Biology Ph.D. program at the University of Colorado in Denver. Both of the undergraduate students are women and their work on the project supports NSF’s goal to increase the participation of members from underrepresented groups in science. The graduate student working on the project was Wade Borcherds. He is a co-author on a book chapter and four published manuscripts. He is currently working as a post-doc in the lab.

During the funding period, I developed a program to interact with K-12 students in the Tampa area. This program is called Modeling Molecules and Marvelous Magnets. This program is designed to introduce K-12 students to important concepts in structural biology and to increase their enthusiasm about science. The program was unveiled to a group of boys from a local scout troop on July 15, 2011. The embedded figure shows some highlights from this event. The program lasts about 1.5 hours and begins with a short presentation where students are guided through a visual description of simple molecules, like water and amino acids. During this part of the presentation students are given an opportunity to build models of these simple molecules. A small amount of funding will be used to purchase a dozen model-building kits so that more students can participat...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The research objectives for award MCB-0939014 are to determine structural ensembles for a set of orthologous proteins that are intrinsically unstructured and use these ensembles to identify relationships between sequence identity and structural similarity. Major accomplishments during the funding period include the development of a new method for analyzing the structural ensembles of intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPDs). This method bypasses traditional structure based approaches by performing principle component analysis directly on atomic contact maps. We also made a comprehensive comparison of evolutionary models for ordered and disordered proteins and showed that infrequent residues found in the protein binding sites of IDPDs are highly conserved. More recently, in collaboration with Dr. Ytreberg, a new method was developed that combines experiment and computer simulations to generate all atom structural ensembles of IDPDs. One published book chapter and two published manuscript demonstrates that it performs well with both small angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) data and NMR chemical shifts and for the first time demonstrates that common structural features can be detected in multiple independently generated ensembles. We also recently demonstrated that disorder predictors could reliably predict the backbone dynamics of a family of IDPDs and for this same family we showed that structural divergence is more extensive than sequence divergence. In collaboration with Dr. Phil Selenko and Dr. Alexander Loewer we demonstrated that the levels of disorder and residual helicity in an IDP controlled its ability to function properly in the test tube and inside living cells. Broader impacts of the current NSF support include training postdoctoral scientists, undergraduate students and graduate students. Two postdoctoral scientists, Hongwei Wu and Stepan Kashtanov, have worked on the project. Dr. Wu is a co-author on one book chapter and five published manuscript. He recently accepted a Research Faculty position at the University of Indiana Chemistry Department. Dr. Kashtanov is a co-author on one book chapter and two published manuscripts. Two undergraduate students have worked on the project. One of these students, A. Stancik, is a co-author on a published manuscript and is currently a research technician in a former colleagues laboratory at the University of Idaho. The other student, K. Mishal, received an REU supplement to work on the project in Summer 2010 and is a co-author on the Nature Chemical Biology pubication from 2014. She recently accepted an appointment to the Cancer Biology Ph.D. program at the University of Colorado in Denver. Both of the undergraduate students are women and their work on the project supports NSFÆs goal to increase the participation of members from underrepresented groups in science. The graduate student working on the project was Wade Borcherds. He is a co-author on a book chapter and four published manuscripts. He is currently working as a post-doc in the lab. During the funding period, I developed a program to interact with K-12 students in the Tampa area. This program is called Modeling Molecules and Marvelous Magnets. This program is designed to introduce K-12 students to important concepts in structural biology and to increase their enthusiasm about science. The program was unveiled to a group of boys from a local scout troop on July 15, 2011. The embedded figure shows some highlights from this event. The program lasts about 1.5 hours and begins with a short presentation where students are guided through a visual description of simple molecules, like water and amino acids. During this part of the presentation students are given an opportunity to build models of these simple molecules. A small amount of funding will be used to purchase a dozen model-building kits so that more students can participate.
